intro: Anethum graveolens subsp. segetum, commonly known as cumin, is an annual herbaceous plant native to the Mediterranean region and parts of South Asia. It is characterized by its slender, branched stems and feathery, aromatic leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers arranged in umbels, which are typical of the Apiaceae family. Its seeds, which are harvested for their distinctive flavor and aroma, are widely used in culinary and medicinal applications. The plant thrives in well-drained soils and prefers full sun, making it adaptable to a variety of growing conditions.
